The Whips - the victims of much rumour, myth
and speculation but about whom little is still known.

107.text:
Shadowy figures who skulk around Westminster
moving in mysterious ways and bound by shared

114.text:
secrets - few of which have ever been revealed.
Past and present Whips will have conversations

121.text:
on what is known as 'Whips terms' - a firm
promise of a secret to be shared and a secret

127.text:
to be kept. However not all have kept their
secrets as secret as they should! Giles Brandreth,

134.text:
MP for Chester from 1992-97 and Government
Whip for two years, was said to have broken

141.text:
the code of the Whips and outraged many when
he published his diaries. Giles Brandreth

147.text:
probably rightly described the Whips office
as “an office of curious customs and practices”

153.text:
but did he reveal all? A few tit bits to wet
the appetites of those reading the fly cover

159.text:
only!
And tonight I may disappoint. The advert that

163.text:
was sent out ahead of this evening's lecture
made mention of 'the mysterious world of intrigue'

169.text:
to draw you in with the tantalising suggestion
that ALL is to be revealed. I can tell you

175.text:
much but I am NOT intending to make Daily
Mail headlines tomorrow! So - few secrets

181.text:
revealed but importantly I do hope to be able
to give some insight into the times, trials,

188.text:
tribulations and work of the modern day Whips
Office. However I use the term 'modern' loosely.

197.text:
The Houses of Parliament are slow to change
their ways and modern can refer to anything

201.text:
in the last 50 years!
To illustrate this point you only need to

206.text:
back to the 1850's when it was said of the
Whips, "they are ready to perform any trick

212.text:
or dodge for the benefit of their party' - some
journalist could have said that yesterday.

217.text:
But it may have given rise to the comment
from around the same time from Robert Peel

222.text:
who said that the post of the Whip was "a
place which requires a gentleman to fill it

227.text:
and which no gentleman would take,"
However closer to the truth today, former

233.text:
Chief Whip Tim Renton in his book said that,
"a good whip is not just a sergeant major.

240.text:
He (or she) is also a counsellor and a nanny.
The Whips listen everywhere - in the tea room,

245.text:
in the library and watch who is talking to
whom and they also keep watch on who the journalists

251.text:
are talking to." This forward thinking former
Chief Whip of nearly 1/4 Century ago gives

257.text:
away his modernity by referring to 'he or
she'. The mere thought that a woman could

262.text:
be a Whip was an extraordinary suggestion
until 1964 when Harriet Slater, a Labour MP,

269.text:
was the first woman appointed to the Government
Whips Office - actually they still probably

273.text:
thought it was an extraordinary suggestion
in 1964! The Whips Offices - traditionally

279.text:
the place for ex union heavies or ex military
types - the Whips Offices were never in any

287.text:
History
Before moving much further along - a word

290.text:
about the terminology. The Whips are Members
of Parliament appointed by the Party leader

295.text:
- the Prime Minister if that Party is in Government.
As distinct from ‘The Whip’ which is the

300.text:
document circulated weekly by the Whips of
each party to their own members and lists

306.text:
the business for the following week, together
with when votes are expected. The importance

311.text:
of an item of Parliamentary business used
to be reflected by how many times it was underlined

318.text:
hence the phrase ‘three line whip’. In
recent times a 3 line Whip is always seen

324.text:
as an unbreakable commitment with a 2 line
and a 1 line Whips being seen as of less importance.

331.text:
However the days of literally underlining
the forthcoming Parliamentary Business has

335.text:
gone as we rely so much less on paper communication.
But only just - when I was first elected 2005

344.text:
it was still just about in use, disappearing
with the increasing use of email and text

349.text:
- but the phraseology has remained. I understand
from the history books that at one time there

356.text:
could be as many as 6 lines of underlining!
One wonders what the 6, 5 and 4 line Whips

362.text:
all meant. However MPs lives in times gone
past were complex. Being an MP was very much

368.text:
a part time job, MPs were not paid until the
early 20th century so gathering MPs to Parliament

376.text:
was probably a more complex affair requiring
more detailed instructions about the importance

385.text:
I did find a reference to what is thought
to be the first record of a written Whip.

391.text:
It wasn't referred to as such but it was 'a
call to Parliament'. On 25th November 1621

399.text:
Sir George Calvert, who was a Member of Parliament
and one of James 1st's Secretaries of State,

405.text:
wrote to Sir Julius Caesar (and yes there
really was an MP by that name, representing

410.text:
Reigate amongst several other places!). Sir
George requested Caesar’s attendance in

415.text:
Parliament on the following day and said,
‘every day as long as the house sits to

420.text:
lay the Kings necessitates before Parliament”.
Which is much the same as we would say today:

426.text:
'On Monday, 9th March there will be a 3 line
Whip from 3.30pm till all Government business

431.text:
is secured' . So 400 years hasn't changed
much albeit with a message written and delivered

437.text:
by very different means!
It is difficult to put the Whips Office in

443.text:
any historical context without looking at
the changes in how legislation was taken through

450.text:
Parliament, the reduced influence of the monarch
and the rise of the stronger party political

455.text:
affiliations we have today. The Parliamentary
world in which the political leaders of the

460.text:
last few centuries was very different from
now and so also the job of the Whips. It is

467.text:
also the case that on looking through some
of the historical accounts there are some

471.text:
conflicting anecdotes. But what becomes clear
is that the Whips and whipping appears to

478.text:
have emerged without anyone really noticing
- and in the rather shadowy way one would

483.text:
expect everything to do with the Whips to
be!

487.text:
The expression 'Whip' has its origins in hunting
terminology. The term 'whipper-in' is the

493.text:
huntsman's assistant who keeps the hounds
from straying by driving them back with the

498.text:
whip into the main body of the pack. It is
said that every hunt has to have a 'whipper

504.text:
in' whose job it is to ensure the hounds do
not stray. I don't think MPs would like to

510.text:
be referred to as hounds but I think one gets
the picture! Indeed according to the some

515.text:
historical records, the first use of the term
‘whipper-in’ in a Parliamentary sense

520.text:
occurred in 1772 - and I quote "he was first
a whipper-in to the Premier". However one

527.text:
can find various references to Whips before
then - Whips and Whipping goes back a long

532.text:
way! In the debate of 8th May 1769, Edmund
Burke talked of calling his friends back and

540.text:
said he was “whipping them in, to which
there could not be a better phrase." And if

546.text:
we go even further back to 18th November 1742,
one of the Finch family (Earls of various

552.text:
places like Nottingham, Winchelsea and Aylesford)
remarked in a letter to Lord Malton that "the

559.text:
Whigs for once in their lives have whipped
in better than the Tories". So the term, the

564.text:
practise of getting people into Parliament
for votes, and persuading them to vote in

569.text:
a certain way goes back many hundreds of years.
It's not surprising. Anyone who is leading

576.text:
a cause - Parliamentary or otherwise - will
always need to 'whip' their followers to be

585.text:
The title ‘Chief Whip’ cannot be dated
exactly, and appears to have been formalised

589.text:
in the early nineteenth century. All political
parties will have an effective Chief Whip

595.text:
but the term usually refers to the Chief Whip
of the Government of the day. The Chief Whip

600.text:
administers the Whipping system including
the supervision of the Whips below them. The

605.text:
Chief Whip is also formally known as Parliamentary
Secretary to the Treasury although the title

611.text:
is rarely used these days. The Chief Whip
attends Cabinet and until quite recently was

617.text:
always a member of the Cabinet. The Chief
Whip also used to hold the unofficial title

622.text:
of Patronage Secretary or Secretary for Political
Jobs but this is only used now with a mixture

630.text:
of irony and humour - there isn't so much
patronage to be handed out! Recent changes

636.text:
in Parliament have reduced the opportunities
for patronage even further and many decisions

642.text:
that were previously in the hands of the Chief
Whip are now decided by Parliament as a whole

648.text:
- eg membership of the Select Committees.
A few remain and a few key decisions are still

655.text:
taken in the Whips Offices - including. Interestingly,
what office accommodation is given to the

662.text:
MPs of their party. And critically for the
ambitious MP the Chief Whip and indeed the

668.text:
Whips collectively, are still key to the success
- or not - of an MP's Parliamentary career.

676.text:
The Whips' recommendations to the Leader of
their Party or to the Prime Minister hold

680.text:
considerable weight. We are friends worth
making and friends worth keeping!

688.text:
However back to the first known holders of
the title Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury

693.text:
- they were just that! In the sixteenth century
they were no more than personal servants to

700.text:
the Treasurer – acting as his scribe and
confidential secretary. However by the Restoration

706.text:
the Parliamentary Secretary became an important
administrative official carrying out some

711.text:
of the functions that were considered essential
to the business of the Treasurer.

716.text:
And the secretaries or ministers of the day
would often be named as tellers - those that

720.text:
stand at the doors of the division lobbies
and count the MPs who come through. The tellers

725.text:
were therefore in prime position to know who
was a friend and who was the foe of the government

731.text:
of the day - and indeed still are. The position
of teller was a powerful job and highly political.

738.text:
The tellers, the secretaries, had important
information about who had received favours

743.text:
from the Government - patronage was in ample
supply - MPs received pensions, contracts,

750.text:
assistance in elections for themselves and
their friends. So when it came it ‘whipping

755.text:
in the votes’, the secretaries knew who
was in the Government’s debt - who owed

760.text:
the Government - and they also knew who had
not repaid the Government with their support

769.text:
So the Parliamentary Secretaries were closely
connected with the Prime Minister and with

774.text:
the administrative work of the Treasury office.
The secretaries therefore were skilled in

779.text:
financial matters, became skilled in the technique
of parliamentary procedure, and they often

784.text:
served on committees appointed to bring in
bills. They knew a lot, had their fingers

789.text:
in many pies and were therefore a powerful
bunch.

794.text:
But that's not it - lets return to the Chief
Whip - the Parliamentary Secretary to the

799.text:
Treasury - the Patronage Secretary. In days
gone by he also had hard cash to dole out

805.text:
and he administered the Secret Service Fund
which was technically Kings money. So in the

811.text:
18th Century, the Patronage Secretary was
described - not unsurprisingly - as a “rather

819.text:
roguish office”.
By the beginning of the 20th century the Office

822.text:
of the Chief Whip was well established. And
although some of that patronage had disappeared

829.text:
over the course of the previous century, the
arrangement of Government business in the

833.text:
House, the organisation of MPs attendance
in Parliament, making sure important divisions

839.text:
were won, gathering of intelligence on MPs,
dishing out jobs and other political offices

845.text: - all lay in the Chief Whip's hands.

850.text:
By the early 20th century, we see the work
of the Whips increasingly commented upon.

855.text:
There are some very amusing quotes and again
you could easily be forgiven for thinking

861.text:
that some were written yesterday - one particularly
struck me “There was also a growing tendency

868.text:
for members to grow restive about the activities
of the party Whips” - still the case I suspect!

875.text:
And MPs became increasingly aware of the extent
to which their own domestic comfort depended

881.text:
on the Whips. Don't forget it was the Whips
who arranged the timetable of the House, gave

887.text:
members permission to go home or go on holiday,
and arranged the order of speakers in debate.

892.text:
By 1910 they had come to be among the best-known
Parliamentary figures. Critics of Parliament

900.text:
were prone to suggest that the Whips exercised
a sort of tyranny over MPs and that they had,

907.text:
destroyed the independence of the Commons
- outrageous suggestion but nothing much has

914.text:
Today
But let's move on to today and where we are

918.text:
now.
The primary role of the Chief Whip (and the

921.text:
Whips) is to get the Government’s business
through Parliament. In particular to make

926.text:
sure the Government gets a majority on the
votes on its legislation. So, that means - as

932.text:
it always has done - keeping MPs informed
of forthcoming Parliamentary business, making

938.text:
sure MPs attend important debates, and support
their party in any votes. The Whips make sure:

944.text:
that there are enough speakers in debates;
that the key debating points are made; and

949.text:
as Abel mentioned in the 50’s, have the
job of “cheering the Minister”. For regular

954.text:
watchers of Parliament, the cries of 'hear
hear' are often instigated by the Whip on

961.text:
the bench. There is always a Whip sitting
on the front bench - noting down who speaks

966.text:
well, who has performed badly and if any Points
of Order are raised that have implications

971.text:
for a Minister. And always keeping an eye
on the business to make sure everyone is in

977.text:
their place when they should be. Although
much of the Parliamentary business is limited

982.text:
by time constraints' it doesn't necessarily
mean all that time will be used. So items

988.text:
of Parliamentary business can begin earlier
than anticipated. If you are watching Parliament

995.text:
and see a Whip frantically running around,
it's probably a Whip desperately trying to

1000.text:
locate the Minister who didn't realise the
next item of business started early and they

1005.text: need to be at the dispatch box!

1007.text:
For the poor Whip, as they are Ministers - if
no Departmental Minister is present, then

1016.text:
it's the Whip who has to stand in for them
- give a speech made up on the spot and with

1022.text:
no briefing!
Whips also have a Whitehall Department or

1025.text:
two to work with and they will be responsible
for managing any Bills that department brings

1030.text:
forward. They will also have a flock of about
25 MPs who they look after and there are also

1036.text:
other administrative responsibilities that
are divided between them - for instance one

1042.text:
will be in charge of liaising with the Clerks
of the House each day about how the business

1047.text:
and votes are managed. And I've mentioned
the accommodation Whip already which is another

1052.text:
Parliament sometimes feels like a stage with
the Whips as the stage managers - the Whips

1058.text:
turn the lights on at the beginning of the
day, make sure it all runs smoothly and put

1063.text:
the cat out and turns the lights off at the
end of the day.

1067.text:
Through the Chief Whip along with business
managers, the Leader of the House, the Prime

1072.text:
Minister and with some collaboration of the
Whitehall Departments the business of the

1077.text:
House is arranged. No small feat when one
considers the administrative arrangements

1083.text:
for a Bill. It all starts with the publication
of a Bill or draft Bill; then possible pre

1090.text:
legislative scrutiny; the a day for the 2nd
Reading must be found on the floor of the

1095.text:
House; then committee stages need to be timetabled
for several weeks at a time; then a day or

1100.text:
two for the Report Stage of the Bill again
on the floor of the House along with 3rd Reading;

1104.text:
then off it goes down to - what we call the
other end - so the Lords if the Bill started

1108.text:
in the Commons. And then the whole process
repeated at the other end. Then back the bill

1113.text:
comes to where it started for consideration
of Lords amendments on the floor of the House.

1117.text:
Then finally 'ping pong' where the Bill can
be batted to and fro from one end to the other

1123.text:
And there may be several bills on the go at
the same time - confused - you wouldn't be

1128.text:
alone! That's just one of the jobs that the
Chief Whip will need to organise. The Chief

1134.text:
Whip is in charge of mapping out the detailed
timing for the Government's programme of business

1139.text:
and estimating the likely time needed through
the usual channels (a word about that curious

1145.text:
phase in a minute). But also mindful of the
other constraints' on time due to standing

1150.text:
orders and statute law which require business
to be completed by certain dates.

1157.text:
But Whipping is also a job of management and
persuasion. The stories about the techniques

1163.text:
used by the Whips to persuade backbenchers
are often exaggerated. But as traditionally

1170.text:
Whips never speak about their work -with regard
to the truth of stories you may have heard

1176.text:
- in the words of Francis Urquhart - I couldn’t
possibly comment. The vow of silence on entering

1182.text:
the Whips office is unbreakable.
However these days there is certainly an important

1188.text:
element of carrot as well as stick in the
way Whips persuade Members to do the right

1193.text:
thing and support their Party. Whips today
need to be good personal managers. It's not

1201.text:
just about telling people what to do its about
passing messages up to those making decisions,

1208.text:
explaining why some MPs might have a problems
with policy or legislation and passing messages

1214.text:
back down. It's about making sure very over
worked Ministers take the time to meet back

1220.text:
benchers and explain the issues - it's a job
that needs sensitive handling to find compromise.

1227.text:
Therefore the Chief Whip has an important
role advising the Cabinet and the PM about

1234.text:
the likely acceptability of its legislative
proposals to the backbenchers.

1240.text:
A less well known side of the Whips work is
to provide a link between the Government and

1247.text:
Opposition parties and other important figures
within Parliament. These relationships are

1253.text:
often referred to as the ‘usual channels’
- I mentioned this earlier. The usual channels

1258.text:
- the largely informal and private network
of communication that the Whips Office operate.

1266.text:
Through the usual channels unbreakable gentlemen's
agreements are made to organise the timetabling

1272.text:
of committees, the distribution between parties
of select committee chairs, when votes occur

1279.text:
and a whole host of other issues. And in particular
‘pairing’ to make sure that some leeway

1285.text:
is given to MPs who cannot be there for votes
due to illness, family circumstances or cross

1291.text:
party trips away from Westminster. The surprising
thing about the Whips office is that you work

1298.text:
closer with the Opposition Parties than in
any other role.

1303.text:
There is also support from civil servants
who work to help the usual channels run smoothly

1310.text:
acting as non-partisan deal-brokers between
the Government and Opposition parties. A notable

1317.text:
feature of the post of Private Secretary to
the Chief Whip is the length of service of

1322.text:
previous office holders; since the creation
of the post in 1919 there have only been four

1329.text: Private Secretaries - must be a fun job

1332.text:
So how many of us are there? There is the
Chief Whip, the Deputy Chief Whip and then

1338.text:
three of the Government Whips are officially
members of Her Majesty’s Household. The

1344.text:
Deputy Chief Whip is the Treasurer of the
Household; then there is the Comptroller of

1348.text:
the Household and Vice-Chamberlain of the
Household (that's me). The Whips who are Members

1354.text:
of the Royal Household accompany the Sovereign
and Royal Household at various diplomatic

1359.text:
and social events..
The next layer down in the Government Whips

1362.text:
Office are the Lord Commissioners of the Treasury
- they get to sign off certain documents and

1368.text:
sometimes even cheques by virtue of their
office. And then there are the junior Whips.

1375.text:
Whips even though they are non departmental
Ministers are silent on everything! They are

1381.text:
a policy free zone - and they don’t speak
or sign anything - but for those reasons - they

1389.text:
get priority access to Ministers about constituency
matters.

1396.text:
Finally a word about my Role
I am the Whip who holds the title of Vice-Chamberlain

1401.text:
to Her Majesty's Household. I am one of those
three Whips who are Members of the Royal household.

1407.text:
The role of Vice Chamberlain dates back to
the reign of Edward III and there are only

1413.text:
5 women to have ever held the post. I am given
a white staff as a wand of office by Her Majesty

1419.text:
the Queen and together with the other 2 Members
of the Royal Household we walk down the Queen's

1424.text:
passage at garden parties with our white staves
and along with the royal equerries find suitable

1430.text:
guests for the Lord Chamberlain to introduce
to the Queen.

1435.text:
In a tradition which has its origins in the
seventeenth century, before the Queen’s

1440.text:
speech at the State Opening of Parliament
all three of us travel to Buckingham Palace

1445.text:
carrying our ceremonial white staves. However
the Vice Chamberlain doesn't return straight

1451.text:
away! The Vice Chamberlain is kept prisoner
during the State Opening and has to remain

1459.text:
at Buckingham Palace as a hostage for the
Queen’s safe return. It was said that should

1464.text:
a group of militant anti-monarchists manage
to abseil down from the public galleries during

1470.text:
the Queen’s speech and snatch Her Majesty
from under their Lordship’s noses, the hapless

1476.text:
Vice-Chamberlain would find himself or herself
indefinitely detained in the Palace - well

1483.text: there could be worse places to be detained!

1487.text:
The Vice Chamberlain writes to Her Majesty
every day and the letter is printed out and

1491.text:
put in her red box every night. The purpose
is to inform Her Majesty about what has happened

1497.text:
in the House that day. Although it is well
known that she enjoys something reasonably

1503.text:
light hearted with a few snippets of tea room
gossip as well. The Vice-Chamberlain also

1509.text:
presents herself to the House of Commons to
report the Queen’s answers to addresses

1514.text:
from the House. For me this role deserved
a pair of high heeled shoes - something I

1519.text:
never wear. When I was appointed I decided
that it had to be high heels - the boys wear

1525.text:
morning dress - so for me walking backwards
in high heels brought a new challenge to my

1533.text:
And there we have it - a quick look at the
Whips and Whipping.

1536.text:
Do you know more than when I began? I hope
so

1540.text:
Do you know about the things you REALLY really
wanted to know? I hope not

1545.text:
Because if you did I would have betrayed some
secrets.

1548.text:
But I hope what I have shared is an insight
into how the Whips Office operates in one

1555.text:
of the greatest democratic institutions in
the world.

1560.text:
In the House of Commons on 11th November 1947
Churchill said, "Democracy is the worst form

1567.text:
of government, except for all those other
forms that have been tried from time to time."

1572.text:
And I have to agree.
It's by no means perfect but with elections

1578.text:
a short time ahead we should remember to value
what we have. Nurture it, improve it but value

1585.text:
it.
And remember how lucky we are. Around the

1589.text:
world - every minute of every day - someone
will be putting their life at risk to fight

1595.text:
for the right to vote.
We have that right and we should use that

1599.text:
right whenever we are given the opportunity.
If you or someone you know is thinking about

1606.text:
not voting - I would ask you to ask them - to
give a thought for that which they discard

1614.text:
so easily - when others would literally die
for the right and the privilege to do so.
